clarifying_information.clarifying_question1: Are you interested in how the optical and photostability properties of semiconducting polymers compare to other imaging agents (like quantum dots, metallic nanoparticles, or organic dyes) specifically for early-stage tumor detection?

clarifying_answer1.clarifying_answer: Yes, I am specifically interested in how the optical and photostability properties of semiconducting polymers compare with other imaging agents—such as quantum dots, metallic nanoparticles, or organic dyes—in the context of early-stage tumor detection.

clarifying_information.clarifying_question2: Would you like a detailed comparison of the biocompatibility and safety profiles of semiconducting polymers versus traditional inorganic and organic biomaterials in the context of clinical tumor imaging?

clarifying_answer2.clarifying_answer: Yes, please provide a detailed comparison of the biocompatibility and safety profiles of semiconducting polymers versus traditional inorganic and organic biomaterials specifically in the context of clinical tumor imaging.

clarifying_information.clarifying_question3: Are you looking for insights on the advantages of semiconducting polymers in multimodal and theranostic (diagnosis plus therapy) tumor detection applications compared to other available nanoparticle-based biomaterials?

clarifying_answer3.clarifying_answer: Yes, I am interested in understanding the specific advantages of semiconducting polymers compared to other nanoparticle-based biomaterials, especially regarding their efficacy and effectiveness in multimodal and theranostic tumor detection and treatment applications.

sections.title: Introduction to Nanomaterials for Tumor Detection
sections.tldr: Nanomaterials including semiconducting polymers, quantum dots, metallic nanoparticles, and organic dyes have emerged as powerful tools for early-stage tumor detection due to their unique optical properties. Each class of nanomaterial offers distinct advantages and limitations for biomedical imaging and detection applications. (LLM Memory)
sections.text: Nanomaterials have revolutionized early-stage tumor detection by offering superior optical properties compared to conventional imaging agents. These materials generally range from 1-100 nm in size and include several distinct classes with unique characteristics for biomedical applications. Semiconducting polymers (SPs) are conjugated polymers with delocalized π-electrons that provide strong absorption and emission properties with high quantum yields. Their fully organic composition, structural flexibility, and tunable properties make them particularly promising for biological applications. Quantum dots (QDs) are inorganic semiconductor nanocrystals with size-dependent optical properties, offering narrow emission bands, broad excitation spectra, and exceptional brightness. Metallic nanoparticles (MNPs), particularly gold and silver, exhibit surface plasmon resonance that enables strong light scattering and absorption, making them valuable contrast agents. Organic dyes, the most traditional fluorophores, are small molecules with conjugated structures that provide good brightness but often suffer from limited stability. The fundamental differences in composition, size, and electronic structure between these nanomaterials directly influence their effectiveness in tumor detection applications. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Optical Properties Comparison
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymers offer superior brightness, photostability, and biocompatibility compared to quantum dots and organic dyes. Quantum dots provide tunable emission and narrow spectral profiles but face toxicity concerns, while metallic nanoparticles excel in surface plasmon resonance applications. (23 sources)
sections.text:
The optical properties of nanomaterials are critical determinants of their efficacy in early-stage tumor detection. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs/Pdots) possess exceptional optical characteristics that often surpass other nanomaterials. They exhibit extinction coefficients one order of magnitude higher than quantum dots and two orders of magnitude greater than organic dyes, resulting in remarkable brightness <Paper corpusId="252560850" paperTitle="(Riahin et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that semiconducting polymer dots can be up to 10 times brighter than commercial fluorescent dyes <Paper corpusId="221467278" paperTitle="(Siddique et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> and approximately 5 times brighter than quantum dots under identical experimental conditions <Paper corpusId="42624892" paperTitle="(Rong et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

Quantum dots (QDs) offer their own distinctive optical advantages, including size-tunable light emission, broad excitation spectra, and narrow emission bands <Paper corpusId="14621486" paperTitle="(Xing et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="17310914" paperTitle="(Zou et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Their molar extinction coefficients are 10-50 times greater than typical organic dyes, making them up to 20 times brighter <Paper corpusId="21848769" paperTitle="(Suffredini et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. QDs also demonstrate sharp emission peaks and strong signal intensity, with single QDs having longer fluorescence lifetime and 10-20 times higher signal strength than organic fluorescent dyes <Paper corpusId="246432045" paperTitle="(Lou et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Their ability to provide multiple separated emission peaks under the same excitation wavelength makes them particularly suitable for multiplexed detection of biomarkers <Paper corpusId="246432045" paperTitle="(Lou et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="259514890" paperTitle="(Chen et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Photostability is a critical parameter for optical imaging applications. Semiconducting polymers demonstrate outstanding photostability, allowing for single particle tracking with emission of up to 10^9 photons prior to irreversible photobleaching <Paper corpusId="252560850" paperTitle="(Riahin et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="13265422" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2008)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, QDs exhibit decreased rates of photobleaching compared to organic dyes <Paper corpusId="21848769" paperTitle="(Suffredini et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>, with the ability to remain fluorescent for months <Paper corpusId="276093448" paperTitle="(Nunziata et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. In contrast, traditional organic dyes often suffer from rapid photobleaching and self-fluorescence issues <Paper corpusId="54100812" paperTitle="(Cohen et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="33729982" paperTitle="(Saleh, 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

A unique advantage of SPNs over QDs is that their emission properties are not size-dependent <Paper corpusId="59488513" paperTitle="(Hashim et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>, while their absorption and emission characteristics can be tuned by modifying the molecular structure of the polymer <Paper corpusId="254732880" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. SPNs also feature large absorption coefficients, allowing for enhanced sensitivity in photoacoustic imaging <Paper corpusId="253274990" paperTitle="(He et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="31038259" paperTitle="(Zhou et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. 

Unlike QDs, which face toxicity concerns due to heavy metal content <Paper corpusId="257134662" paperTitle="(Guo et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="250730791" paperTitle="(Kang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>, SPNs are composed of biologically inert organic materials with minimal cytotoxicity <Paper corpusId="209247990" paperTitle="(Gao et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="252560850" paperTitle="(Riahin et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This favorable biocompatibility profile makes SPNs particularly promising for clinical translation.

For NIR-II imaging (1000-1700 nm wavelength), SPNs such as PDFT1032 demonstrate excellent properties including high photostability, favorable absorption peaks, large Stokes shifts, and outstanding biocompatibility <Paper corpusId="19105574" paperTitle="(Shou et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. These properties enable deeper tissue penetration and higher resolution imaging compared to imaging in traditional wavelength ranges <Paper corpusId="259742069" paperTitle="(Su et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

In the realm of metallic nanoparticles, their distinct surface plasmon resonance properties allow for strong light scattering and absorption, though their extinction coefficients may be lower than those of SPNs <Paper corpusId="85447855" paperTitle="(Maturi et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Metallic nanoparticles remain valuable as contrast agents for specific imaging applications but face limitations in terms of optical tunability and photostability compared to semiconducting polymers and quantum dots.

Organic dyes, while widely used due to their availability and established protocols, generally exhibit lower brightness, poorer photostability, and smaller Stokes shifts compared to the other nanomaterials <Paper corpusId="99161006" paperTitle="(Kemal et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Their application in advanced bioimaging is increasingly limited by these inherent optical constraints, particularly for deep-tissue and long-term imaging applications.

paper.title: Near Infrared Emitting Semiconductor Polymer Dots for Bioimaging and Sensing

snippets: Pdots have several desirable properties that make them attractive alternatives to other luminescent nanoparticles. The high brightness of Pdots is owed to their fast emissive rates and large extinction coefficients (Pecher et al., 2010). Since each monomer with the polymer chain is capable of absorbing incident light, the high concentration of chromophores in Pdots gives them extinction coefficients an order of magnitude higher than luminescent quantum dots and two orders of magnitude greater than organic dyes (Li et al., 2018). Furthermore, Pdots are highly resistant to photobleaching, which make them excellent candidates for fluorescence imaging and sensing applications (Wu et al., 2008)
Finally, Pdots exhibit minimal or no cytotoxicity towards mammalian cells which distinguish them from heavy metal, cadmium and lead containing quantum dots (Gidwani et al., 2021).

Multiplexed molecular imaging enables multiplexed imaging of large panels of cancer biomarkers. Polymer dots can be used in multiplexed molecular imaging and utilizes semiconducting polymers with strong fluorescence. Studies show a 10-fold enhanced brightness of polymer dots over commercial fluorescent dyes. Quantum dots are fluorescent semiconductor NPs that typically contain group II-VI (e.g., CdSe and CdTe), III-V (e.g., InP and InAs), IV-VI (e.g., PbTe, PbSe), or I-III-VI (e.g., CuInS 2 ) elements.

paper.title: Multicolor conjugated polymer dots for biological fluorescence imaging.

snippets: Highly fluorescent conjugated polymer dots were developed for demanding applications such as fluorescence imaging in live cells. These nanoparticles exhibit small particle diameters, extraordinary fluorescence brightness, and excellent photostability. Single particle fluorescence imaging and kinetic studies indicate much higher emission rates (approximately 10(8) s(-1)) and little or no blinking of the nanoparticles as compared to typical results for single dye molecules and quantum dots. Analysis of single particle photobleaching trajectories reveals excellent photostabilityas many as 10(9) or more photons emitted per nanoparticle prior to irreversible photobleaching. The superior figures of merit of these new fluorescent probes, together with the demonstration of cellular imaging, indicate their enormous potential for demanding fluorescence-based imaging and sensing applications such as high speed super-resolution single molecule/particle tracking and highly sensitive assays.

snippets:
QDs can provide images across large ranges of wavelengths and have high quantum yields (Alivisatos, 1996). Unlike organic dyes, which often suffer rapid photo-bleaching [75](Iyer et al., 2008), QDs are composed of semiconducting metals (e.g., Cd, Zn, Se, In, P, and As) that are resistant to photo-bleaching (260588791). 

Furthermore, the quantum properties of QDs are tunable and can provide excitation/emission wavelengths ranging from ultraviolet (UV) to NIR. The outer shell of the QD could be modified by organic layers including PEG polymers, phospholipids, and peptides (Wang et al., 2011), thus preventing nonspecific absorption of proteins to their surface, increase blood half-life, and reducing toxicity (Hauck et al., 2010)(Jokerst et al., 2011)

Although QDs offer potentially valuable benefits in preclinical oncology, such as drug targeting and in vivo biomedical imaging, under certain conditions, they pose risks to human health and the environment, constituting a barrier for their translation to clinical use (Hardman, 2005). Semiconducting polymer dots have aroused extensive interests as a novel family of fluorescent probes for tumor targeting applications (Lee et al., 2010)(Cheng et al., 2014). Unlike QDs, polymer-based dots were developed from biologically non-toxic materials, using deep-red photo-acceptors and visible-light photo-donors.

paper.title: Detection: From Electrochemistry to Spectroscopy with Chromatographic Techniques, Recent Trends with Nanotechnology

snippets: Fluorescent quantum dots (QDs), of a semiconductor core such as cadmium, mixed with selenium or tellurium, surrounded by a semiconductor outer shell, often zinc sulphide, and a layer of polymer to stabilize the QD, and allow for (bio-)chemical functionalization, are of unique optical properties when compared to conventional semiconductors, organic fluorescent dyes, and proteins. QDs offer excellent photostability and tunable emission spectra from the ultraviolet to the near infrared region, simply by modulating their size. Due to their photostability, QDs avoid the problems of self-absorption, self-fluorescence, and photobleaching from which traditional fluorophores suffer. Therefore, QDs offer applications within many different areas, including waterborne pathogen detection (Ibáñez-Peral et al., 2008)

Polymeric nanoparticles encapsulate a fluorophore within a polymeric coating like fluorescent silica nanoparticles have been applied for detection using fluorescence spectrometers or fluorescent reading microtiter plate readers, as well as in flow cytometry. The protection of the fluorophore by the polymer provides high stability under a range of conditions proving superior to organic dyes in terms of photostability and versatility (Kaittanis et al., 2010).

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) are uorescent materials which are proposed as alternatives to inorganic quantum dots. SPNs have better uorescence stability with longer shelf-lives, are composed of benign or less-toxic materials, and can be synthesized by an environmentally friendly and relatively easy method (miniemulsion) that does not require any heating, and can be performed in ambient conditions. Many applications require uorescence within a specic range of wavelengths, selected for the relevant end-use. Nanoparticles engineered for these applications must, therefore, have stable emission that does not change or quench in their intended environment over the period of storage and use. Unlike quantum dots, SPNs have emission colors that do not shi with the change in their size.

paper.venue: Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Nanomedicine and Nanobiotechnology

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) are a new class of photonic materials with great potential for biomedical applications. Owing to their large absorption coefficients, tunable optical properties, and high photostability, SPNs have recently been used to improve the sensitivity and resolution of photoacoustic (PA) imaging. In particular, a number of strategies have been explored to design activatable SPNs for amplified in vivo PA imaging. In this review, the recent advances in the development of SPNs as exogenous PA contrasts agents have been summarized and their promising potential as multifunctional probes for cancer theranostics has been discussed. This article is categorized under: Diagnostic Tools > In Vivo Nanodiagnostics and Imaging.

snippets: Up to now, a variety of inorganic nanomaterials, such as carbon nanotubes (Diao et al., 2015), quantum dots [19](Awasthi et al., 2020), and rare earth nanoparticles (NPs) (Wang et al., 2017)(Naczynski et al., 2013), have been widely explored for NIR-II FLI, but their long-term biotoxicity and minimal biodegradability could substantially hinder their practical applications (Lei et al., 2020). Small molecular organic dyes exhibit superiority in the aspect of biocompatibility, but they often suffer from unsatisfactory photostability and limited accumulation capacity (Lyu et al., 2018)(Zhang et al., 2017). In contrast, semiconducting polymers (SPs) with large π-conjugated architectures exhibit reliable biosafety, strong light-harvesting ability, durable photostability, excellent photothermal conversion ability, etc. They have manifested great talents in the fields of FLI, photoacoustic imaging, and imaging-guided PTT and/or photodynamic therapy (Sun et al., 2018)(Song et al., 2020)(Guo et al., 2018)(Jiang et al., 2018)(Feng et al., 2013)(Li et al., 2018)(Yu et al., 2017)(Qi et al., 2022).

sections.title: Photostability Comparison
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymers demonstrate superior photostability compared to other nanomaterials, showing exceptional resistance to photobleaching and maintaining their optical properties during long-term imaging. While quantum dots also exhibit good photostability, organic dyes suffer from rapid photobleaching, and metallic nanoparticles show variable stability depending on their composition. (12 sources)
sections.text:
Photostability is a critical parameter for effective tumor detection applications, as it determines the ability of imaging agents to maintain their optical properties during extended imaging sessions. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) demonstrate outstanding photostability, which is one of their most significant advantages over other nanomaterials. Multiple studies confirm that SPNs exhibit excellent resistance to photobleaching and maintain their optical performance during prolonged imaging periods <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="210873619" paperTitle="(Ni et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This exceptional photostability allows SPNs to be utilized for long-term cell tracking applications with minimal signal degradation <Paper corpusId="210873619" paperTitle="(Ni et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="139966816" paperTitle="(Ni et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

A key advantage of SPNs is their resistance to reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are abundant in biological environments. Research has shown that SPNs are generally more resistant to ROS and significantly more photostable than gold nanorods, allowing for reliable imaging in living animals where ROS concentrations can reach micromolar levels <Paper corpusId="52111480" paperTitle="(Zhu et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This chemical stability in oxidative environments contributes to their overall superior performance in biological applications.

Quantum dots (QDs) also exhibit strong photostability compared to traditional fluorophores. They show improved resistance against photobleaching and can remain fluorescent for months, making them suitable for longitudinal imaging studies <Paper corpusId="14621486" paperTitle="(Xing et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>. However, while QDs demonstrate good photostability, they face significant concerns regarding toxicity due to their heavy metal content, limiting their clinical applications <Paper corpusId="209247990" paperTitle="(Gao et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

In contrast, organic dyes, which have been widely used in biomedical imaging, suffer from poor photostability and low quantum yields in aqueous biological environments <Paper corpusId="90340197" paperTitle="(Hassan et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Their rapid photobleaching significantly restricts their utility for extended imaging applications, particularly in in vivo settings <Paper corpusId="221660902" paperTitle="(Xie et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. 

Metallic nanoparticles show variable photostability depending on their composition and structure. While they generally offer better photostability than organic dyes, they typically do not match the exceptional stability of semiconducting polymers <Paper corpusId="232382625" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Their non-biodegradable nature and potential long-term toxicity remain significant concerns for clinical applications <Paper corpusId="232382625" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

For second near-infrared (NIR-II) window applications, which enable deeper tissue penetration, the photostability of imaging agents becomes even more critical. Studies have demonstrated that semiconducting polymer nanoparticles like PDFT1032 possess excellent photostability in the NIR-II window, along with favorable absorption peaks and large Stokes shifts <Paper corpusId="19105574" paperTitle="(Shou et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. These properties make them particularly suitable for deep-tissue and long-term tumor imaging applications.

The unique combination of high photostability, excellent biocompatibility, and lack of emission intermittency (non-blinking) positions SPNs as superior contrast agents for reliable cross-platform imaging techniques, including confocal microscopy, multiphoton fluorescence microscopy, and light-sheet ultramicroscopy <Paper corpusId="13679120" paperTitle="(Feng et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="258745886" paperTitle="(Bortot et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. These advantages, coupled with their tunable optical properties, make semiconducting polymers particularly promising for early-stage tumor detection applications where imaging reliability and signal persistence are crucial.

paper.title: Nanoparticle-based Cell Trackers for Biomedical Applications

snippets: In comparison with the traditional fluorescent probes such as endogenous biomolecules and fluorescent proteins, fluorescent NPs exist unique advantages of higher brightness, tunable fluorescence and better photobleaching resistance (Ni et al., 2018). In this section, we focus on a series of fluorescent NPs (Sahl et al., 2017) for cell tracking, including inorganic quantum dots (QDs) (Zhao et al., 2018)(Li et al., 2015), nanodiamonds (Hsiao et al., 2016)(Hsiao et al., 2016), and organic NPs (Ni et al., 2018)(Feng et al., 2018). For organic NPs, we emphasize on aggregation-induced emission (AIE) dots (Feng et al., 2018)(Cai et al., 2016)(Qi et al., 2018) and semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) (Li et al., 2014)(Jiang et al., 2018)(Li et al., 2019) as cell trackers, resulting from their excellent photostability, long-term cell tracking ability, and good biocompatibility (Huang et al., 2019)(Jin et al., 2015)(Qin et al., 2014).

paper.title: Fluorescent Nanoparticles for Noninvasive Stem Cell Tracking in Regenerative Medicine.

snippets: Stem cell-based therapies have emerged as promising platforms with the potential to treat serious diseases that are incurable by traditional medical approaches. To optimize the overall outcomes, it is important to understand the fate of transplanted stem cells (e.g., localization, migration, engraftment, survival, proliferation and differentiation). Fluorescent nanoparticles with good photostability and minimal perturbation of cell functions hold great promise for distinguishing transplanted stem cells from host tissues with high resolution, showing advantages over traditional histological methods. This review aims to summarize the recent advances in the use of fluorescent nanoparticles for the direct labelling of stem cells and the applications of such nanoparticles in stem cell tracking. The relevant fluorescent nanoparticles, including quantum dots, organic fluorogen-doped nanoparticles, fluorescent nanodiamonds, and upconversion nanoparticles are discussed. The advantages and limitations of the currently available fluorescent trackers are summarized, and perspectives on new research opportunities are discussed.

paper.title: In vivo multiphoton fluorescence imaging with polymer dots

snippets:
Organic dyes, however, suffer from poor photostability and low quantum yields in aqueous biological environments. 13.14,15 Although quantum dots offer improved brightness and photostability, they present substantial toxicity concerns and are prone to bioaccumulation in organs and tissues. 16,17,18 Thus, the biological imaging community is eager for a safer, brighter, and more stable probe for deep, high-resolution in vivo imaging.

The highly fluorescent semiconducting polymer dot (pdot) is a promising candidate for in vivo MPM with material properties that can potentially overcome many of the limitations faced by other probes. 19 Although pdots are similar to quantum dots with respect to size (5-50 nm) and quantum yield, pdots are brighter, more photostable, and present no clear evidence of biotoxicity. 19,20 A useful measure of fluorescence brightness is the action cross section, which is given by the product of the peak absorption cross section and the fluorescence quantum yield. 19,21 Polymer dots rival both quantum dots and organic dyes in that their two-photon action (2PA) cross-sections are one to two orders of magnitude larger than inorganic quantum dots and three to five orders of magnitude greater than commonly used fluorescent dyes. 19,22

paper.title: Aggregation-Induced Emission (AIE) Dots: Emerging Theranostic Nanolights.

snippets: Theranostic nanolights refer to luminescent nanoparticles possessing both imaging and therapeutic functions. Their shape, size, surface functions, and optical properties can be precisely manipulated through integrated efforts of chemistry, materials, and nanotechnology for customized applications. When localized photons are used to activate both imaging and therapeutic functions such as photodynamic or photothermal therapy, these theranostic nanolights increase treatment efficacy with minimized damage to surrounding healthy tissues, which represents a promising noninvasive nanomedicine as compared to conventional theranostic approaches. As one of the most promising theranostic nanolights, organic dots with aggregation-induced emission (AIE dots) are biocompatible nanoparticles with a dense core of AIE fluorogens (AIEgens) and protective shells, whose sizes are in the range of a few to tens of nanometers. Different from conventional fluorophores that suffer from aggregation-caused quenching (ACQ) due to π-π stacking interaction in the aggregate state, AIEgens emit strongly as nanoaggregates due to the restriction of intramolecular motions. Through precise molecular engineering, AIEgens could also be designed to show efficient photosensitizing or photothermal abilities in the aggregate state. Different from ACQ dyes, AIEgens allow high loading in nanoparticles without compromised performance, which makes them the ideal cores for theranostic nanolights to offer high brightness for imaging and strong photoactivities for theranostic applications. In this Account, we summarize the recent advance of AIE dots and highlight their great potential as theranostic nanolights in biomedical applications. Starting from the design of AIEgens, the fabrication of AIE dots and their bioimaging applications are discussed. The exceptional advantages of superbrightness, high resistance to photobleaching, lack of emission intermittency, and excellent biocompatibility have made them reliable cross platform contrast agents for different imaging techniques such as confocal microscopy, multiphoton fluorescence microscopy, super-resolution nanoscopy, and light-sheet ultramicroscopy, which have been successfully applied for cell tracking, vascular disease diagnosis, and image-guided surgery. The integration of therapeutic functions with customized AIEgens has further empowered AIE dots as an excellent theranostic platform for image-guided phototherapy. Of particular interest is AIE photosensitizer dots, which simultaneously show bright fluorescence and high photosensitization, yielding superior performance to commercial photosensitizer nanoparticles in image-guided therapy. Further development in multiphoton excited photodynamic therapy has offered precise treatment with up to 5 μm resolution at 200 μm depth, while chemiexcited photodynamic therapy has completely eliminated the limitation of penetration depth to realize power-free imaging and therapy. With this Account, we hope to stimulate more collaborative research interests from different fields of chemistry, materials, biology, and medicine to promote translational research of AIE dots as the theranostic nanolights.

sections.title: Biocompatibility and Toxicity Considerations
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymers demonstrate superior biocompatibility with minimal cytotoxicity compared to other nanomaterials, making them more suitable for clinical applications. Quantum dots face significant limitations due to heavy metal toxicity concerns, while metallic nanoparticles raise issues about long-term accumulation, and organic dyes generally show good biocompatibility but with other performance limitations. (18 sources)
sections.text:
Biocompatibility and toxicity profiles are critical considerations for nanomaterials intended for tumor detection, as they directly impact clinical translation potential. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs/Pdots) offer exceptional biocompatibility advantages over other nanomaterials. They are composed of fully organic, biologically inert constituents that naturally overcome the long-term toxicity issues associated with inorganic nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="218550859" paperTitle="(Xu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51905347" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Multiple studies have confirmed that SPNs exhibit minimal or no cytotoxicity toward mammalian cells, making them particularly promising for in vivo applications <Paper corpusId="252560850" paperTitle="(Riahin et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="235644177" paperTitle="(Shrestha et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The biocompatibility advantage of SPNs becomes particularly evident when compared to quantum dots (QDs). While QDs offer excellent optical properties, their clinical translation faces significant barriers due to their composition. Most QDs contain heavy metals (e.g., Cd, Zn, Se, In, P, and As) that raise serious toxicity concerns <Paper corpusId="54100812" paperTitle="(Cohen et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="221467278" paperTitle="(Siddique et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that QDs can potentially disrupt mitochondrial function and lead to DNA damage, which presents a major obstacle to their clinical translation <Paper corpusId="250730791" paperTitle="(Kang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. These inherent toxicity issues have driven researchers to explore alternative nanomaterials like SPNs that maintain similar optical advantages without the associated biological risks <Paper corpusId="257134662" paperTitle="(Guo et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Metallic nanoparticles, while useful as imaging agents, face biocompatibility challenges primarily due to their non-biodegradable nature and potential for long-term accumulation in tissues. Research indicates that their persistence in biological systems raises concerns about chronic toxicity that remain unresolved <Paper corpusId="232382625" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This limitation significantly impacts their suitability for repeated clinical applications or longitudinal studies.

Organic dyes generally demonstrate good biocompatibility compared to inorganic nanomaterials <Paper corpusId="259742069" paperTitle="(Su et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. However, their application is often limited by other factors such as poor photostability and limited accumulation capacity in target tissues rather than toxicity concerns <Paper corpusId="259742069" paperTitle="(Su et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="224931609" paperTitle="(Yin et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

A unique characteristic of SPNs is their resistance to reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are abundant in biological environments, especially in tumor tissues. Studies have demonstrated that SPNs are generally more resistant to ROS than other nanomaterials such as gold nanorods, allowing for reliable imaging in living animals where ROS concentrations can reach micromolar levels <Paper corpusId="52111480" paperTitle="(Zhu et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This chemical stability in oxidative environments further enhances their biocompatibility profile and contributes to their overall superior performance in biological applications.

The organic and potentially biodegradable nature of semiconducting polymers provides additional advantages for long-term clinical applications. Unlike inorganic nanomaterials that may persist in tissues indefinitely, SPNs can be designed with biodegradable components that facilitate their elimination from the body after serving their diagnostic purpose <Paper corpusId="260861329" paperTitle="(Dunn et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="59488513" paperTitle="(Hashim et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. This property is particularly valuable for repeated imaging procedures where accumulation of imaging agents could otherwise pose risks.

The exceptional biocompatibility of SPNs has enabled their successful application in various biomedical contexts, including fluorescence imaging, photoacoustic imaging, and photothermal therapy <Paper corpusId="260675119" paperTitle="(Elgiddawy et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="272668437" paperTitle="(Yin et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Their minimal toxicity, combined with their outstanding optical properties, positions them as highly promising agents for early-stage tumor detection applications where patient safety is paramount <Paper corpusId="99161006" paperTitle="(Kemal et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="234149323" paperTitle="(Idiago-Lopez et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have found tremendous success in recent years as promising theranostic agent owing to their good optical properties, high photostability and outstanding biocompatibility (Li et al., 2019)(Jiang et al., 2019)(Li et al., 2019)(Li et al., 2019)(Hu et al., 2019)

SPNs are composed of organic constituents with low cytotoxicity and thus naturally overcome the long term toxicity issue caused by inorganic nanoparticles (Long et al., 2020)(Jiang et al., 2018)(Miao et al., 2018)(2017).

paper.title: Multimodal Biophotonics of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles.

snippets: Biophotonics as an interdisciplinary frontier plays an increasingly important role in modern biomedical science. Optical agents are generally involved in biophotonics to interpret biomolecular events into readable optical signals for imaging and diagnosis or to convert photons into other forms of energy (such as heat, mechanical force, or chemical radicals) for therapeutic intervention and biological stimulation. Development of new optical agents including metallic nanoparticles, quantum dots, up-conversion nanoparticles, carbon dots, and silica nanoparticles has contributed to the advancement of this field. However, most of these agents have their own merits and demerits, making them less effective as multimodal biophotonic platforms. In this Account, we summarize our recent work on the development of near-infrared (NIR) semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as multimodal light converters for advanced biophotonics. SPNs are composed of π-electron delocalized semiconducting polymers (SPs) and often possess the advantages of good biocompatibility, high photostability, and large absorption coefficients. Because the photophysical properties of SPNs are mainly determined by the molecular structures of the precursor polymers, molecular engineering allows us to fine tune their photophysical processes to obtain different optical responses, even to light in the second NIR window (1000-1700 nm). Meanwhile, the facile nanoformulation methods of SPNs enable alteration of their outer and inner structures for diverse biological interactions. The unique photophysical properties of SPNs have brought about ultrasensitive deep-tissue molecular imaging. NIR-absorbing SPNs with strong charge-transfer backbones can convert photoenergy into mechanical acoustic waves, permitting photoacoustic imaging that bypasses the issue of light scattering and reaches the centimeter tissue penetration depth. Differently, phenylenevinylene-containing SPNs can store photon energy via chemical defects and emit long-NIR afterglow luminescence with a half-life of ∼6 min after cessation of light excitation. Such an afterglow process avoids tissue autofluorescence, giving rise to ultrahigh signal-to-background ratios. So far, SPN-based molecular photoacoustic or afterglow probes have been developed to image disease tissues (tumors), biomarkers (biothiols and reactive oxygen species), and physiological indexes (pH and temperature) in different preclinical animal models. The synthetic flexibility of SPNs further permits light-modulated biological and therapeutic interventions. Till now, SPNs with high photothermal conversion efficiencies have been shaped into photothermal transducers to remotely regulate biological events including protein ion channels, enzymatic activity, and gene expression. In conjunction with the desired biodistribution and tumor-homing ability, SPNs have been doped or coated with other inorganic agents for amplified photothermal or self-regulated photodynamic cancer therapy. This Account thus demonstrates that SPNs serve as a multimodal biophotonic nanoplatform to provide unprecedented opportunities for molecular imaging, noninvasive bioactivation, and advanced therapy.

paper.title: Near Infrared Emitting Semiconductor Polymer Dots for Bioimaging and Sensing

snippets: Pdots have several desirable properties that make them attractive alternatives to other luminescent nanoparticles. The high brightness of Pdots is owed to their fast emissive rates and large extinction coefficients (Pecher et al., 2010). Since each monomer with the polymer chain is capable of absorbing incident light, the high concentration of chromophores in Pdots gives them extinction coefficients an order of magnitude higher than luminescent quantum dots and two orders of magnitude greater than organic dyes (Li et al., 2018). Furthermore, Pdots are highly resistant to photobleaching, which make them excellent candidates for fluorescence imaging and sensing applications (Wu et al., 2008)
Finally, Pdots exhibit minimal or no cytotoxicity towards mammalian cells which distinguish them from heavy metal, cadmium and lead containing quantum dots (Gidwani et al., 2021).

paper.title: Smart Nanoparticles for Chemo-Based Combinational Therapy

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles [SPNs) have also been used as photothermal agents (Yang et al., 2021)(Lyu et al., 2018)(Jiang et al., 2018). Being made of organic compounds including semiconducting polymers/oligomers and amphiphilic polymers, SPNs possess natural biocompatibility, good photostability, and are easy to functionalize (Jiang et al., 2018). It has been reported that SPNs have relatively higher photothermal conversion efficacy in comparison with carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods. The photophysical properties of SPNs are correlated to the molecular structures of their precursor polymers, which allows versatility and diversity for tuning the optical spectra (Jiang et al., 2019)(Yu et al., 2018)

Organic dyes can absorb optical energy and convert it into heat as well. Organic nanocarriers encapsulating organic dyes have been explored as complement for classic inorganic PTT, since they display good biocompatibility, biodegradability, and low longterm harmfulness.

snippets:
QDs can provide images across large ranges of wavelengths and have high quantum yields (Alivisatos, 1996). Unlike organic dyes, which often suffer rapid photo-bleaching [75](Iyer et al., 2008), QDs are composed of semiconducting metals (e.g., Cd, Zn, Se, In, P, and As) that are resistant to photo-bleaching (260588791). 

Furthermore, the quantum properties of QDs are tunable and can provide excitation/emission wavelengths ranging from ultraviolet (UV) to NIR. The outer shell of the QD could be modified by organic layers including PEG polymers, phospholipids, and peptides (Wang et al., 2011), thus preventing nonspecific absorption of proteins to their surface, increase blood half-life, and reducing toxicity (Hauck et al., 2010)(Jokerst et al., 2011)

Although QDs offer potentially valuable benefits in preclinical oncology, such as drug targeting and in vivo biomedical imaging, under certain conditions, they pose risks to human health and the environment, constituting a barrier for their translation to clinical use (Hardman, 2005). Semiconducting polymer dots have aroused extensive interests as a novel family of fluorescent probes for tumor targeting applications (Lee et al., 2010)(Cheng et al., 2014). Unlike QDs, polymer-based dots were developed from biologically non-toxic materials, using deep-red photo-acceptors and visible-light photo-donors.

snippets: Up to now, a variety of inorganic nanomaterials, such as carbon nanotubes (Diao et al., 2015), quantum dots [19](Awasthi et al., 2020), and rare earth nanoparticles (NPs) (Wang et al., 2017)(Naczynski et al., 2013), have been widely explored for NIR-II FLI, but their long-term biotoxicity and minimal biodegradability could substantially hinder their practical applications (Lei et al., 2020). Small molecular organic dyes exhibit superiority in the aspect of biocompatibility, but they often suffer from unsatisfactory photostability and limited accumulation capacity (Lyu et al., 2018)(Zhang et al., 2017). In contrast, semiconducting polymers (SPs) with large π-conjugated architectures exhibit reliable biosafety, strong light-harvesting ability, durable photostability, excellent photothermal conversion ability, etc. They have manifested great talents in the fields of FLI, photoacoustic imaging, and imaging-guided PTT and/or photodynamic therapy (Sun et al., 2018)(Song et al., 2020)(Guo et al., 2018)(Jiang et al., 2018)(Feng et al., 2013)(Li et al., 2018)(Yu et al., 2017)(Qi et al., 2022).

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) are uorescent materials which are proposed as alternatives to inorganic quantum dots. SPNs have better uorescence stability with longer shelf-lives, are composed of benign or less-toxic materials, and can be synthesized by an environmentally friendly and relatively easy method (miniemulsion) that does not require any heating, and can be performed in ambient conditions. Many applications require uorescence within a specic range of wavelengths, selected for the relevant end-use. Nanoparticles engineered for these applications must, therefore, have stable emission that does not change or quench in their intended environment over the period of storage and use. sections.title: Tumor Detection Applications and Effectiveness
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles demonstrate superior performance in multiple tumor detection modalities including photoacoustic imaging, fluorescence imaging, and photothermal therapy compared to other nanomaterials. Their exceptional brightness, photostability, and biocompatibility make them particularly effective for early-stage tumor detection with higher sensitivity and resolution than conventional imaging agents. (20 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have emerged as powerful tools for early-stage tumor detection across multiple imaging modalities. Their exceptional optical properties make them particularly effective for photoacoustic imaging (PAI), where they serve as contrast agents with advantages over other nanomaterials including organic dyes, metallic nanoparticles, and carbon nanomaterials <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. The high absorption coefficients of SPNs enhance their sensitivity in PAI applications, allowing for improved detection of small tumor masses <Paper corpusId="221660902" paperTitle="(Xie et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232405899" paperTitle="(Rejinold et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231613155" paperTitle="(Zhen et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

SPNs have demonstrated effectiveness in detecting specific tumor biomarkers, particularly reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are abundant in tumor microenvironments. Their ability to function as NIR ratiometric nanoprobes for in vivo imaging of ROS makes them valuable for studying various pathological processes, including tumor metastasis <Paper corpusId="17310914" paperTitle="(Zou et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This capability provides critical information about tumor progression and potential metastatic activity that might be missed by conventional imaging approaches.

Quantum dots (QDs) also show significant utility in tumor detection, particularly for materials with low abundance due to their high quantum yields <Paper corpusId="209392700" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Their superior optical characteristics compared to organic dyes, including size-tunable fluorescence and exceptional photostability, allow them to emit bright, stable signals over extended imaging periods <Paper corpusId="274331986" paperTitle="(Idoko et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="276093448" paperTitle="(Nunziata et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. QDs further enable multiplexed imaging—simultaneous detection of multiple biomarkers in a single scan—which is invaluable for mapping tumor heterogeneity <Paper corpusId="274331986" paperTitle="(Idoko et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="237489934" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Polymer dots (Pdots), a subclass of SPNs, have demonstrated effectiveness in multiplexed molecular imaging of cancer biomarkers with studies showing a 10-fold enhanced brightness over commercial fluorescent dyes <Paper corpusId="221467278" paperTitle="(Siddique et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This enhanced brightness translates to improved detection sensitivity, particularly for early-stage tumors when cancerous masses are still small.

The effectiveness of SPNs extends beyond imaging to theranostic applications, where they serve as both diagnostic and therapeutic agents. Their high photothermal conversion efficiency makes them excellent photothermal agents for cancer therapy, with studies showing that SPNs have relatively higher photothermal conversion efficacy compared to carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods <Paper corpusId="235644177" paperTitle="(Shrestha et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="206718590" paperTitle="(Lyu et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51905347" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This dual functionality enables image-guided cancer therapies, where tumors can be both detected and treated using the same nanoplatform.

Advancements in SPN design have led to the development of thermo-responsive semiconducting polymer nanoparticles specifically designed for high-contrast photoacoustic imaging of tumors <Paper corpusId="276093448" paperTitle="(Nunziata et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. These specialized nanoparticles enhance the differentiation between tumor and healthy tissues, improving diagnostic accuracy. The ability to tune the photophysical properties of SPNs through molecular engineering allows for optimization of their performance for specific tumor types and imaging modalities <Paper corpusId="58648939" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

A significant advantage of SPNs for tumor detection is their ability to operate in the second near-infrared (NIR-II) window (1000-1700 nm), which enables deeper tissue penetration and higher resolution imaging compared to conventional wavelength ranges <Paper corpusId="58648939" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This capability allows for the detection of tumors in deep tissues that might be inaccessible using traditional imaging agents that operate in the visible or first NIR window.

The combination of excellent biocompatibility, photostability, and brightness positions SPNs as "all in one" nanomedicine platforms for imaging-guided dual modality therapy <Paper corpusId="89620074" paperTitle="(Yu et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This integrated approach enables not only sensitive detection of tumors but also monitoring of therapeutic response, offering comprehensive management of cancer from diagnosis through treatment <Paper corpusId="257483691" paperTitle="(Creamer et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="276917234" paperTitle="(Kuddushi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent innovations in SPN formulations have overcome challenges associated with free dyes, such as hydrophobicity, photobleaching, and aggregation-caused quenching, particularly for in vivo applications <Paper corpusId="258745886" paperTitle="(Bortot et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232208201" paperTitle="(Ong et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5531770" paperTitle="(Feng et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. These improvements have further enhanced the effectiveness of SPNs for tumor detection by providing more stable and reliable imaging performance.

paper.title: Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles: Signal Amplification and Second Near-Infrared Construction.

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging and photothermal therapy (PTT) have attracted extensive attention in disease diagnosis and treatment. Although many exogenous contrast agents have been developed for PA imaging and PTT, the design guidelines to amplify their imaging and therapy performances remain challenging and are highly demanded. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) composed of polymers with π-electron delocalized backbones can be designed to amplify their PA imaging and PTT performance, because of their clear structure-property relation and versatility in modifying their molecular structures to tune their photophysical properties. This review summarizes the recent advances in the photoacoustic imaging and photothermal therapy applications of semiconducting polymer nanoparticles with a focus on signal amplification and second near-infrared (NIR-II, 1000-1700 nm) construction. The strategies such as structure-property screening, fluorescence quenching, accelerated heat dissipation, and size-dependent heat dissipation are first discussed to amplify the PA brightness of SPNs for in vivo PA. The molecular approaches to shifting the absorption of SPNs for NIR-II PA imaging and PTT are then introduced so as to improve the tissue penetration depth for diagnosis and therapy. At last, current challenges and perspectives of SPNs in the field of imaging and therapy are discussed.

paper.title: Review on Optical Imaging Techniques for Multispectral Analysis of Nanomaterials

snippets: Biomedical imaging is an essential tool for investigating biological responses in vivo. Among the several imaging techniques, optical imaging systems with multispectral analysis of nanoparticles have been widely investigated due to their ability to distinguish the substances in biological tissues in vivo. This review article focus on multispectral optical imaging techniques that can provide molecular functional information. We summarize the basic principle of the spectral unmixing technique that enables the delineation of optical chromophores. Then, we explore the principle, typical system configuration, and biomedical applications of the representative optical imaging techniques, which are fluorescence imaging, two-photon microscopy, and photoacoustic imaging. The results in the recent studies show the great potential of the multispectral analysis techniques for monitoring responses of biological systems in vivo.

paper.title: Enhancing Both Biodegradability and Efficacy of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy.

snippets: Theranostic nanoagents are promising for precision medicine. However, biodegradable nanoagents with the ability for photoacoustic (PA) imaging guided photothermal therapy (PTT) are rare. We herein report the development of biodegradable semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) with enhanced PA and PTT efficacy for cancer therapy. The design capitalizes on the enzymatically oxidizable nature of vinylene bonds in conjunction with polymer chemistry to synthesize a biodegradable semiconducting polymer (DPPV) and transform it into water-soluble nanoparticles (SPNV). As compared with its counterpart SPN (SPNT), the presence of vinylene bonds within the polymer backbone also endows SPNV with a significantly enhanced mass absorption coefficient (1.3-fold) and photothermal conversion efficacy (2.4-fold). As such, SPNV provides the PA signals and the photothermal maximum temperature higher than SPNT, allowing detection and photothermal ablation of tumors in living mice in a more sensitive and effective way. Our study thus reveals a general molecular design to enhance the biodegradability of optically active polymer nanoparticles while dramatically elevating their imaging and therapeutic capabilities.

paper.title: Multimodal Biophotonics of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles.

snippets: Biophotonics as an interdisciplinary frontier plays an increasingly important role in modern biomedical science. Optical agents are generally involved in biophotonics to interpret biomolecular events into readable optical signals for imaging and diagnosis or to convert photons into other forms of energy (such as heat, mechanical force, or chemical radicals) for therapeutic intervention and biological stimulation. Development of new optical agents including metallic nanoparticles, quantum dots, up-conversion nanoparticles, carbon dots, and silica nanoparticles has contributed to the advancement of this field. However, most of these agents have their own merits and demerits, making them less effective as multimodal biophotonic platforms. In this Account, we summarize our recent work on the development of near-infrared (NIR) semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) as multimodal light converters for advanced biophotonics. SPNs are composed of π-electron delocalized semiconducting polymers (SPs) and often possess the advantages of good biocompatibility, high photostability, and large absorption coefficients. Because the photophysical properties of SPNs are mainly determined by the molecular structures of the precursor polymers, molecular engineering allows us to fine tune their photophysical processes to obtain different optical responses, even to light in the second NIR window (1000-1700 nm). Meanwhile, the facile nanoformulation methods of SPNs enable alteration of their outer and inner structures for diverse biological interactions. The unique photophysical properties of SPNs have brought about ultrasensitive deep-tissue molecular imaging. NIR-absorbing SPNs with strong charge-transfer backbones can convert photoenergy into mechanical acoustic waves, permitting photoacoustic imaging that bypasses the issue of light scattering and reaches the centimeter tissue penetration depth. Differently, phenylenevinylene-containing SPNs can store photon energy via chemical defects and emit long-NIR afterglow luminescence with a half-life of ∼6 min after cessation of light excitation. Such an afterglow process avoids tissue autofluorescence, giving rise to ultrahigh signal-to-background ratios. So far, SPN-based molecular photoacoustic or afterglow probes have been developed to image disease tissues (tumors), biomarkers (biothiols and reactive oxygen species), and physiological indexes (pH and temperature) in different preclinical animal models. The synthetic flexibility of SPNs further permits light-modulated biological and therapeutic interventions. Till now, SPNs with high photothermal conversion efficiencies have been shaped into photothermal transducers to remotely regulate biological events including protein ion channels, enzymatic activity, and gene expression. In conjunction with the desired biodistribution and tumor-homing ability, SPNs have been doped or coated with other inorganic agents for amplified photothermal or self-regulated photodynamic cancer therapy. This Account thus demonstrates that SPNs serve as a multimodal biophotonic nanoplatform to provide unprecedented opportunities for molecular imaging, noninvasive bioactivation, and advanced therapy.

paper.title: Metabolizable Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Second Near‐Infrared Photoacoustic Imaging

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging in the second near‐infrared (NIR‐II) window (1000–1700 nm) holds great promise for deep‐tissue diagnosis due to the reduced light scattering and minimized tissue absorption; however, exploration of such a noninvasive imaging technique is greatly constrained by the lack of biodegradable NIR‐II absorbing agents. Herein, the first series of metabolizable NIR‐II PA agents are reported based on semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs). Such completely organic nanoagents consist of π‐conjugated yet oxidizable optical polymer as PA generator and hydrolyzable amphiphilic polymer as particle matrix to provide water solubility. The obtained SPNs are readily degraded by myeloperoxidase and lipase abundant in phagocytes, transforming from nonfluorescent nanoparticles (30 nm) into NIR fluorescent ultrasmall metabolites (≈1 nm). As such, these nanoagents can be effectively cleared out via both hepatobiliary and renal excretions after systematic administration, leaving no toxicity to living mice. Particularly these nanoagents possess high photothermal conversion efficiencies and emit bright PA signals at 1064 nm, enabling sensitive NIR‐II PA imaging of both subcutaneous tumor and deep brain vasculature through intact skull in living animals at a low systematic dosage. This study thus provides a generalized molecular design toward organic metabolizable semiconducting materials for biophotonic applications in NIR‐II window.

paper.title: Redox-Responsive Dual Chemophotothermal Therapeutic Nanomedicine for Imaging-Guided Combinational Therapy.

snippets: Chemotherapy is currently the major therapeutic method against cancer. However, chemo drugs are usually lacking in the specificity towards cancer cells over normal cells. In this study, we prepared a novel multifunctional trimeric prodrug by linking the chemo drug camptothecin (CPT) and the exceptional photostable near infrared (NIR) croconaine dye (CR) via a glutathione (GSH)-sensitive disulfide linker. Compared with CPT, our novel trimeric CR-(SS-CPT)2 is more hydrophobic and bulky, making it highly effcient to be encapsulated into biocompatible polymeric nanocarrier. The prodrug underwent rapid drug release specifically in cancer cells with high GSH concentration. The hyperthermia produced by CR upon laser irradiation could further accelerate the break of disulfide bond, which makes the release of CPT even more controllable. We further loaded the CR-(SS-CPT)2 into folate modified lipid-polymer nanoparticles, which demonstrated high in vivo tumor accumulation and retention. The biodistribution of these nanoparticles can be directly monitored in real time via NIR fluorescence and photoacoustic imaging. Under the imaging guided chemo- and photothermal- synergistic therapy, the tumors were completely ablated with no recurrence. The design not only highly enhanced the therapeutic specificity and effeciency of CPT, but also provide a "all in one" nanomedicine for imaging-guided dual modality therapy.

paper.title: Recent Advances in Polymeric Nanoparticles for Enhanced Fluorescence and Photoacoustic Imaging.

snippets: In recent years, polymeric nanoparticles (NPs) have become increasingly popular for in vitro and in vivo bioimaging due to their excellent versatility and exceptional optical properties. Following a brief introduction on fluorescence and photoacoustic imaging, as well as the merits of using polymeric NPs over other types of fluorescent probes, this minireview gives a concise summary of key advances made in recent years (2017 - 2020) in the use of polymeric NPs for fluorescence and photoacoustic imaging. We placed a particular focus on various strategies used for enhanced bioimaging applications, including polymeric NPs that encapsulate near-infrared dyes, aggregation-induced emission fluorogens, cationic dyes doped with bulky hydrophobic counterions, and semiconducting polymers. Next, we summarized the current limitations in some of these polymeric NP systems and offered potential solutions to overcome them. Finally, we suggested, from our perspectives, some critical considerations in the design of polymeric NPs for future bioimaging and sensing applications.

paper.title: Conjugated polymer nanoparticles: preparation, properties, functionalization and biological applications.

snippets: In the past few years, conjugated polymer nanoparticles (CPNs) have been successfully prepared and applied in the biological field because of their unique opto-electronic properties. The rapid development of CPNs is mainly attributed to their simple synthesis procedures and easy separation steps. The advantages of CPNs include high brightness, excellent photostability, low cytotoxicity, high quantum yield and versatile surface modification. The functionalization of CPNs with specific recognition elements imparts them good ability for targeted recognition and imaging in vitro and in vivo. CPNs can be applied to deliver drug and gene, and simultaneously to real-time monitor the release process due to their self-luminous characteristics. Moreover, CPNs can sensitize oxygen molecules to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) which can kill adjacent bacteria and tumor cells. In this tutorial review, we provide a recent development of the preparation methods, properties, and functionalization strategies of CPNs, especially discussing their biological applications in targeted imaging, drug/gene delivery and biomedicine. The challenges and outlooks in this field will also be discussed.

sections.title: Advantages and Limitations for Clinical Translation
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymers offer superior clinical translation potential with excellent biocompatibility, photostability, and tunable properties while avoiding the toxicity concerns of quantum dots and metallic nanoparticles. Challenges in standardization, scale-up production, and regulatory approval remain significant barriers to bringing these promising nanomaterials to clinical application. (13 sources)
sections.text:
The clinical translation potential of nanomaterials for tumor detection varies significantly based on their inherent properties and biological interactions. Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) demonstrate the most promising clinical translation profile due to their exceptional combination of biocompatibility, optical performance, and structural versatility. Their composition of fully organic, biologically inert constituents naturally overcomes the long-term toxicity issues associated with inorganic nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="224931609" paperTitle="(Yin et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This favorable safety profile, coupled with high photostability and structural tunability, positions SPNs as ideal candidates for clinical applications where patient safety is paramount <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="21432354" paperTitle="(Cui et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

In contrast, quantum dots (QDs) face significant barriers to clinical translation despite their excellent optical properties. Their core composition typically includes heavy metals such as Cd, Zn, Se, In, P, and As, raising serious toxicity concerns that limit their application in humans <Paper corpusId="250730791" paperTitle="(Kang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that QDs can potentially disrupt mitochondrial function and lead to DNA damage, presenting major obstacles to their clinical adoption <Paper corpusId="257134662" paperTitle="(Guo et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="221467278" paperTitle="(Siddique et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. While surface modifications with PEG polymers, phospholipids, and peptides can reduce toxicity and increase blood half-life, these approaches do not fully mitigate the underlying safety concerns <Paper corpusId="54100812" paperTitle="(Cohen et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Metallic nanoparticles, although widely studied for biomedical applications, face translation challenges primarily due to their non-biodegradable nature and potential for long-term accumulation in tissues. Their persistence in biological systems raises concerns about chronic toxicity that remain unresolved <Paper corpusId="232382625" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, while these materials offer excellent NIR light absorbance and high photothermal efficiency, their clinical adoption is hampered by uncertainties regarding long-term safety <Paper corpusId="259742069" paperTitle="(Su et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Organic dyes, despite their good biocompatibility, face significant limitations for clinical translation due to their poor photostability and low quantum yields in aqueous biological environments <Paper corpusId="90340197" paperTitle="(Hassan et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Their rapid photobleaching and small Stokes shifts severely restrict their utility for extended clinical imaging applications <Paper corpusId="99161006" paperTitle="(Kemal et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. These inherent limitations have driven researchers to explore alternative nanomaterials like SPNs that maintain superior optical advantages without the associated biological risks.

The clinical translation of SPNs benefits from their versatility in both imaging and therapeutic applications. Their dual functionality as diagnostic and therapeutic agents enables image-guided cancer therapies, where tumors can be both detected and treated using the same nanoplatform <Paper corpusId="235644177" paperTitle="(Shrestha et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="206718590" paperTitle="(Lyu et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This theranostic capability is particularly valuable for clinical applications, as it streamlines treatment workflows and potentially reduces costs and complications.

Despite their advantages, all nanomaterials face common challenges in their path to clinical translation. These include batch-to-batch reproducibility, scalable manufacturing, stability during storage, and standardization of characterization methods <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">. Regulatory hurdles also remain significant, as novel nanomaterials must undergo extensive safety and efficacy testing before clinical approval. Additionally, the complexity of functionalization for specific targeting and the optimization of biodistribution profiles present ongoing challenges that researchers must address.

For SPNs specifically, while their biodegradability can be engineered through the incorporation of cleavable linkages, optimizing their clearance pathways to prevent unintended accumulation remains an area requiring further investigation <Paper corpusId="206718590" paperTitle="(Lyu et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. The development of standardized protocols for their synthesis and characterization is also essential to ensure consistent performance across different clinical applications.

In summary, while all nanomaterials discussed offer unique advantages for tumor detection, semiconducting polymers demonstrate the most favorable profile for clinical translation due to their exceptional biocompatibility, photostability, and optical performance. However, addressing manufacturing, regulatory, and optimization challenges remains critical to realizing their full potential in clinical settings.

paper.title: Development of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Photoacoustic Imaging.

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) have evolved into a new class of photonic materials with great potential for biomedical applications. Depending on the polymer structures, SPNs can be developed into optical agents for fluorescence and chemiluminescence imaging, photosensitizers for photodynamic therapy, and heat converters for photothermal therapy. In this feature article, recent work is summarized on the development of SPNs for in vivo photoacoustic (PA) imaging, a state-of-the-art imaging modality that converts light energy into mechanical acoustic waves to provide deep tissue penetration. The structure-property relationship and doping approaches are discussed to reveal the importance of promoting nonradiative decay in amplifying the PA brightness of SPNs. Moreover, their imaging applications, including lymph node mapping, tumor imaging, and monitoring of pathological indexes, are highlighted. These studies demonstrate that SPNs can serve as versatile PA agents for advanced molecular imaging applications.

snippets:
QDs can provide images across large ranges of wavelengths and have high quantum yields (Alivisatos, 1996). Unlike organic dyes, which often suffer rapid photo-bleaching [75](Iyer et al., 2008), QDs are composed of semiconducting metals (e.g., Cd, Zn, Se, In, P, and As) that are resistant to photo-bleaching (260588791). 

Furthermore, the quantum properties of QDs are tunable and can provide excitation/emission wavelengths ranging from ultraviolet (UV) to NIR. The outer shell of the QD could be modified by organic layers including PEG polymers, phospholipids, and peptides (Wang et al., 2011), thus preventing nonspecific absorption of proteins to their surface, increase blood half-life, and reducing toxicity (Hauck et al., 2010)(Jokerst et al., 2011)

Although QDs offer potentially valuable benefits in preclinical oncology, such as drug targeting and in vivo biomedical imaging, under certain conditions, they pose risks to human health and the environment, constituting a barrier for their translation to clinical use (Hardman, 2005). Semiconducting polymer dots have aroused extensive interests as a novel family of fluorescent probes for tumor targeting applications (Lee et al., 2010)(Cheng et al., 2014). Unlike QDs, polymer-based dots were developed from biologically non-toxic materials, using deep-red photo-acceptors and visible-light photo-donors.

snippets: Among the various photothermal agents, organic nanomaterials often have good biocompatibility and biodegradability; however, they also have inherent limitations such as low photothermal conversion efficiency, poor photothermal stability, and complicated synthesis. In contrast, inorganic nanomaterials usually show excellent NIR light absorbance; high photothermal efficiency and photostability owing to their intrinsic optical properties, such as localized surface plasmon resonance (e.g., gold nanomaterials), narrow emission spectra, and structural features that offer advantages such as ease of synthesis and surface modification with different functional groups, including carboxylic, hydroxyl, and epoxy groups (e.g., carbon-based nanomaterials). However, their non-biodegradable nature and potential long-term toxicity remain unsolved issues [27].

paper.title: Precise Planar-Twisted Molecular Engineering to Construct Semiconducting Polymers with Balanced Absorption and Quantum Yield for Efficient Phototheranostics

snippets: Up to now, a variety of inorganic nanomaterials, such as carbon nanotubes (Diao et al., 2015), quantum dots [19](Awasthi et al., 2020), and rare earth nanoparticles (NPs) (Wang et al., 2017)(Naczynski et al., 2013), have been widely explored for NIR-II FLI, but their long-term biotoxicity and minimal biodegradability could substantially hinder their practical applications (Lei et al., 2020). Small molecular organic dyes exhibit superiority in the aspect of biocompatibility, but they often suffer from unsatisfactory photostability and limited accumulation capacity (Lyu et al., 2018)(Zhang et al., 2017). In contrast, semiconducting polymers (SPs) with large π-conjugated architectures exhibit reliable biosafety, strong light-harvesting ability, durable photostability, excellent photothermal conversion ability, etc. They have manifested great talents in the fields of FLI, photoacoustic imaging, and imaging-guided PTT and/or photodynamic therapy (Sun et al., 2018)(Song et al., 2020)(Guo et al., 2018)(Jiang et al., 2018)(Feng et al., 2013)(Li et al., 2018)(Yu et al., 2017)(Qi et al., 2022).

paper.title: In vivo multiphoton fluorescence imaging with polymer dots

snippets:
Organic dyes, however, suffer from poor photostability and low quantum yields in aqueous biological environments. 13.14,15 Although quantum dots offer improved brightness and photostability, they present substantial toxicity concerns and are prone to bioaccumulation in organs and tissues. 16,17,18 Thus, the biological imaging community is eager for a safer, brighter, and more stable probe for deep, high-resolution in vivo imaging.

The highly fluorescent semiconducting polymer dot (pdot) is a promising candidate for in vivo MPM with material properties that can potentially overcome many of the limitations faced by other probes. 19 Although pdots are similar to quantum dots with respect to size (5-50 nm) and quantum yield, pdots are brighter, more photostable, and present no clear evidence of biotoxicity. 19,20 A useful measure of fluorescence brightness is the action cross section, which is given by the product of the peak absorption cross section and the fluorescence quantum yield. 19,21 Polymer dots rival both quantum dots and organic dyes in that their two-photon action (2PA) cross-sections are one to two orders of magnitude larger than inorganic quantum dots and three to five orders of magnitude greater than commonly used fluorescent dyes. 19,22

paper.title: Smart Nanoparticles for Chemo-Based Combinational Therapy

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles [SPNs) have also been used as photothermal agents (Yang et al., 2021)(Lyu et al., 2018)(Jiang et al., 2018). Being made of organic compounds including semiconducting polymers/oligomers and amphiphilic polymers, SPNs possess natural biocompatibility, good photostability, and are easy to functionalize (Jiang et al., 2018). It has been reported that SPNs have relatively higher photothermal conversion efficacy in comparison with carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods. The photophysical properties of SPNs are correlated to the molecular structures of their precursor polymers, which allows versatility and diversity for tuning the optical spectra (Jiang et al., 2019)(Yu et al., 2018)

Organic dyes can absorb optical energy and convert it into heat as well. Organic nanocarriers encapsulating organic dyes have been explored as complement for classic inorganic PTT, since they display good biocompatibility, biodegradability, and low longterm harmfulness.

paper.title: Enhancing Both Biodegradability and Efficacy of Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Photoacoustic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy.

snippets: Theranostic nanoagents are promising for precision medicine. However, biodegradable nanoagents with the ability for photoacoustic (PA) imaging guided photothermal therapy (PTT) are rare. We herein report the development of biodegradable semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) with enhanced PA and PTT efficacy for cancer therapy. The design capitalizes on the enzymatically oxidizable nature of vinylene bonds in conjunction with polymer chemistry to synthesize a biodegradable semiconducting polymer (DPPV) and transform it into water-soluble nanoparticles (SPNV). As compared with its counterpart SPN (SPNT), the presence of vinylene bonds within the polymer backbone also endows SPNV with a significantly enhanced mass absorption coefficient (1.3-fold) and photothermal conversion efficacy (2.4-fold). As such, SPNV provides the PA signals and the photothermal maximum temperature higher than SPNT, allowing detection and photothermal ablation of tumors in living mice in a more sensitive and effective way. Our study thus reveals a general molecular design to enhance the biodegradability of optically active polymer nanoparticles while dramatically elevating their imaging and therapeutic capabilities.
